div.l: How that bigylede was A Carpyntere
ꝐParauenture in skorne For I Am oone
And by your leue I schall hym qwyte anon̄e
Righte in his Churles termes woll I speke
I praye to god his necke Motte to breke
He can well in myne eye seene A stalke
Butte in his owne he can notte sene a balke
Here endith the ꝓprologe of the reve
And begynnyth the tale of the reve
Atte Trumpyngton notte Ferre Frome Cambryge
There gothe A brooke and ouer that A brygge
Vppon he whiche brooke there stante A Mylle
And this is verrey sothe þat I you telle
A Myller was there dwellenge Manye A daye
As enye pecoke he was proude ⁊and gaye
Pypen he couþe And Fysschen ⁊and nettes bete
And turne coppes ⁊and well wrastle ⁊and schete
Ay by his belte he bare A longe pranade
And of a swerde Fulle trenchant was þe blade
A Iolye popper bare he in his powche
There was no Man For parrell durste hym towche
A sheffeld twyttell bare he in his hose
Rounde was his Face ⁊and camuse was his nose
As pyllede as an Ape was his sculle
He was A Markett beter Atte Fulle
There was no wyghte þᵗat durste hande on hym lygge
Butte yete he swore he schulde Anon Abygge
A Thefe he was Forsoþe of Corne ⁊and Mele
And that a slyghe vsande For to stele
His name was hoten deynous symkyn
A wyfe he hadde comen of noble kynne
The ꝑperson of the towne her Fadre was
With her he yafe Fulle Manye A panne of brasse
For þat symken schulde in his blode Allye
Sche was y Fostrede in A Nonnerye
